contentrichtext.text: {{Criminal procedure (trial)}} The '''Speedy Trial Clause''' of the [[Sixth Amendment to the United States Constitution]] provides that "[i]n all criminal prosecutions, the accused shall enjoy the right to a speedy . . . trial . . . ."<ref>U.S. Const. amend. VI.</ref> The Clause protects the defendant from delay between the presentation of the indictment or similar charging instrument and the beginning of trial. In ''[[Barker v. Wingo]]'' (1972), the Supreme Court developed a four-part test that considers the length of the delay, the reasons for the delay, the defendant's assertion of his right to a speedy trial, and the prejudice to the defendant. A violation of the Speedy Trial Clause is cause for dismissal with prejudice of a criminal case. ==Speedy trial statutes== {{see also|Speedy Trial Act}} In addition to the constitutional guarantee, various state and federal statutes confer a more specific right to a speedy trial. The prosecution must be "ready for trial" within six months on all felonies except [[murder]], or the charges are dismissed by action of law without regard to the merits of the case. ==See also== ;Historic origin *[[Assize of Clarendon]] ;Similar international rights *[[Article 6 of the European Convention on Human Rights]] *[[Section Eleven of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==Further reading== *{{cite journal |last=Nicholaidis |first=N. |year=1989 |title=Sixth Amendment Right to a Speedy and Public Trial |journal=American Criminal Law Review |volume=26 |issue=4 |pages=1489â€“1505 |id={{NCJ|122967}} }} ==External links== *[http://law.jrank.org/pages/18569/Fair-Trial-Criminal.html#ixzz0k5eGq3O7 Fair Trial, Criminal - Impartiality., Speedy Trial., The Right to Confront Witnesses., Prejudicial Publicity and Cameras in Court] {{US Constitution}} {{Sixth Amendment|speedy|state=expanded}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Speedy Trial}} [[Category:United States constitutional criminal procedure]] [[Category:Speedy Trial Clause case law|*]] [[Category:Clauses of the United States Constitution]] {{Criminal-law-stub}}
